reimbursement: In the United States, patients with schizophrenia who are unable to work may be eligible for programs such as Medicare and Medicaid. If individuals begin to work and earn a sufficient salary, they may lose these benefits, and it is often the case that the job they are able to maintain provides minimal or no health benefits. The situation can get complicated for coverage and reimbursement

The impact of the U.S. Affordable Care Act (ACA) on the care of individuals with schizophrenia is not yet known. Preexisting conditions are no longer a barrier to getting insurance, and annual and lifetime benefit limits have been removed. The ACA mandates parity of care for medical and psychiatric illnesses
presentation signs and symptoms: Presentation –Most persons with schizophrenia experience negative symptoms first, followed by the onset of positive symptoms(5) –Negative symptoms -Avolition – “An inability to initiate and persist in goal directed activities”(5) -“Flattening” of the individual’s affect(2,5) -Alogia – “A diminution of thoughts that is reflected in decreased fluency and productivity of speech”(5) -Anhedonia – “Lack of pleasure in actions normally pleasurable or lack of satisfaction when activities are performed well”(2) -Apathy(6) -Social and occupational dysfunction(6) –Positive symptoms -Hallucinations: “Abnormal sensory perceptions in the absence of external stimuli”;(5,7) examples include: -auditory hallucinations -Most frequently observed type of hallucination(5)  -visual hallucinations -Hallucinations can occur in any sensory system(7) -Delusions(5,7) -Defined as “fixed false beliefs that involve both misperceptions and misinterpretations”(7) -An example of a delusion – The individual may state that a publication (e.g., newspaper) was encrypted and had a significance only he or she could understand -Disorganized speech(3,5) -“Grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior”(3,5) –Schizophrenia does not occur often in children, but there is increased awareness of childhood-onset schizophrenia(25)

Other manifestations –Reduction in cognitive abilities(6) –Atypical movements(3) –Atypical muscle tone(3) –Dysdiadochokinesia(3) –Astereognosis(3) –Increased rate of blinking(3) –Reduced ability to decipher right and left(3) –Impulsivity –Inappropriate affect (e.g., laughing in the absence of appropriate stimulus)(5) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Obtain informed consent prior to assessment –The ability of a patient with schizophrenia to make fully informed decisions about his or her care may be impaired, making it difficult to ensure that consent is informed, voluntary, and competent

causes: A generally accepted theory is that certain environmental factors (during the initial stages of life) coupled with anindividual’s particular genetic makeup lead to the development of schizophrenia(2,7)
pathogenesis: An overactive dopamine system may contribute to schizophrenia. Elevated levels of dopamine are present along withan increased number of D2 receptors in the basal ganglia and mesolimbic system; this is believed to lead to the positivesymptoms observed in individuals with schizophrenia(3)
Negative symptoms, as well as cognitive impairment, have been proposed as being due to reduced dopamine uptake in thearea of the prefrontal cortex(3)
Structural changes have been detected in the brains of individuals with schizophrenia, including (but not limited to)ventricular enlargement and reduced gray matter(6,7)
risk factors: Family history/genetics–A combination of genetics and environment account for risk, with genetics accounting for 70% of the risk(6)–Having a mother with schizophrenia poses an elevated risk for the development of schizophrenia(8)-Based on a study using data from 2,276,309 people born in Denmark, 1955-1990-Analysis of the data revealed the following-6,476 individuals obtained medical intervention for a schizophrenia spectrum disorder (schizophrenia, schizotypaldisorder, and schizoaffective disorders)-609 individuals developed cannabis-induced psychosis-Maternal schizophrenia posed a heightened risk for the development of schizophrenia in children (5-fold  increased

overall contraindications precautions: Approximately 50% of all individuals with schizophrenia have alcoholism; therefore, the overall risk of falls is heightened in this group(9)

Aggression may be associated with schizophrenia, although spontaneous assault is not common.(5) Aggression occurs more in younger males and in individuals with a history of violence, nonadherence to treatment, substance abuse, and impulsivity(5)

Approximately 20% of patients with schizophrenia attempt suicide on one or more occasions, and many more have significant suicidal ideation.(5) Clinicians should promptly report suicidal thoughts or ideation to appropriate practitioners or authorities

Extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotic medications prescribed for schizophrenia can occur (see  Motor function assessment , below). Patients experiencing extrapyramidal side effects should be referred promptly to their prescribing physician, as some extrapyramidal side effects can become severe and permanent if not addressed

Make sure that discussions with the patient and/or caregiver are conducted in settings where confidentiality and privacy can be assured. Ask the patient what information can be shared with the caregiver

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -Not applicable

course of treatment.medical management: May include the following Hospitalization, as indicated by severity of symptoms(3) Prescription medication(3) Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT), as indicated by severity of symptoms(3) Transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) shows promise for decreasing negative symptoms(26) In a double blind randomized controlled clinical trial conducted in the Netherlands, researchers found that patients had a significant reduction of negative symptoms at 3 month followup Study included 32 patients with schizophrenia or schizo-affective  disorder More studies are needed to determine the optimal treatment parameters for the rTMS Recommendations for psychotherapeutic treatments (e.g., cognitive-behavioral therapy)(3) The authors of a Cochrane systematic review found that the use/impact of physical restraints or seclusion has not been investigated (in randomized controlled trials) in individuals with profound mental illness(10)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications have been prescribed by the patient’s clinician(s); are they being taken? Are they effective?(11) Risperidone (Risperdal) Olanzapine (Zyprexa)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnosis is based on the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders , Fifth Edition  (DSM-5 ) diagnostic criteria for schizophrenia(5)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture, art therapy) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document any reported aggravating or easing factors
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of positive and negative symptoms
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Rating of symptoms -Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 0-10 scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much ) -A study involving 25 individuals with schizophrenia or an acute schizophrenia-like  psychotic disorder and 29 healthy individuals was conducted and the authors found that individuals with schizophrenia may have significantly greater pain thresholds (compared to healthy individuals); however, V AS ratings may be comparable to those of healthy individuals.(12)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night. The patient’s sleep pattern may be altered (e.g., daytime sleeping and nighttime activity)(5)
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/ or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., the patient appears to be experiencing an acute exacerbation of symptoms)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Ask about patient’s smoking history. Over half of people with schizophrenia smoke cigarettes regularly.(5) Any history of coughing, wheezing, or shortness of breath? Does patient report any activity limitation for respiratory reasons? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________ -Some individuals with schizophrenia lack insight or awareness of their disorder, and this may persist throughout the course of their illness.(5)Unawareness (“anosognosia”) is the leading predictor of nonadherence to treatment(5) -Cognitive impairment, which may include problems with attention and concentration, psychomotor speed, memory, and abstract thinking, can be a significant barrier to learning

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Is there any history of autism spectrum disorder (ASD) or a communication disorder of childhood onset? If there is a history of childhood onset of ASD or a communication disorder, the additional diagnosis of schizophrenia is made only if there are prominent delusions or hallucinations in addition to other schizophrenia symptoms required for diagnosis(5) Patients may have received treatment for related cognitive and functional disorders without the specific diagnosis of schizophrenia
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, orthopedic disorders, substance abuse, etc. Weight gain, diabetes, metabolic syndrome, and cardiovascular and pulmonary disease are more common in persons with schizophrenia than in the general population(5) Schizophrenia is associated with increased risk of cardiovascular disease, suicide (as a cause of premature mortality), and substance abuse disorders (including tobacco and alcohol)(7)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in recreational sports or regular physical activity? -Does the patient work or attend school? Describe the required tasks -Making educational progress or maintaining employment are often impaired by the manifestations of schizophrenia, even when the patient’s cognitive skills are sufficient to do the required work(5) -The reliability and validity of the Short-Form International Physical Activity Questionnaire (IPAQ) was investigated in a group (n = 35) of individuals with schizophrenia(13) -The correlation coefficient for reliability was reported to be 0.68 -The correlation coefficient for criterion validity was reported to be 0.37 -The authors concluded that the IPAQ may be a useful instrument for evaluating the physical activity levels of patients with schizophrenia
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document current functional level and the need for assistance with ADLs
social and occupational history.living environment: Does the patient have an adequate living arrangement and adequate social support? With whom does the patient live? Are family members or other caregivers involved? Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? Does the family appear to understand the scope of the patient’s diagnosis? Is the family supportive? Family involvement may reduce morbidity; however, family stress can precipitate relapse and rehospitalization(6) -In the United States, individuals with schizophrenia constitute nearly one third of all homeless people(6)

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.) Patients with schizophrenia may be referred to physical therapy for the management of associated features such as movement disorders or for the management of other conditions
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Calculate patient’s BMI. Obesity is a common health issue for patients with schizophrenia(13)
relevant tests and measures.balance: Complete a balance assessment and document any impairments. The Berg Balance Scale or other standardized balance assessment tool can be used
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Gait/locomotion –Observe gait and document any deviations. Note step and stride length, cadence, step width, and posture during gait. Measure gait speed using the 10-meter  walk test (10MWT). The Dynamic Gait Index (DGI) can be used to assess safety with ambulation –Men with schizophrenia, particularly those who have alcoholism, may present with gait and balance deficits(9) -Based on a study that investigated 4 distinct groups of men -Group 1 – Individuals with schizophrenia and alcohol dependence (n = 10) -Group 2 – Individuals with schizophrenia (non-alcohol  dependent) (n = 10) -Group 3 – Individuals with alcohol dependence (without schizophrenia) (n = 24) -Group 4 – Age-matched  healthy control subjects (n = 27) -Gait and balance was evaluated using the Walk-a-Line Ataxia Battery (completed with eyes shut and open)  -Results -The first 3 groups were significantly more impaired (in areas of gait and balance) than the control subjects (group 4) -Group 1 demonstrated significantly greater impairment than group 3 -The authors note that prescription medications could have had some level of impact on the results –While walking, individuals with schizophrenia may have reduced stride length and gait velocity(14) -Based on a study involving 56 participants (14 control subjects without schizophrenia and 42 individuals with schizophrenia) -The individuals with schizophrenia were grouped by medication status -The participants were evaluated during gait over ground and while on a treadmill (set at 3 different speeds) -Results when walking over ground – Significant results were as follows for individuals with schizophrenia compared to the control subjects -Reduced gait velocity -Reduced stride length -Results when walking on the treadmill – Significant results were as follows for individuals with schizophrenia compared to the control subjects -At the slowest speed stride length was significantly reduced -At the fastest speed, no significant differences were detectedComplete an assessment of joint integrity as indicated by symptoms or reason for referral Motor function (motor control/tone/learning) –Motor coordination may be impaired(5) -The individual may present with dysdiadochokinesia(3) –Assess muscle tone, as it may be atypical(3) –Other neurological soft signs common in patients with schizophrenia include impairments in sensory integration and in motor sequencing of complex movements, left-right confusion, loss of fine motor movement, and disinhibition of associated movements(5) –Assess for presence of extrapyramidal symptoms -Extrapyramidal symptoms are possible side effects with all anti-psychotics,(7) although they are less common with newer, more commonly used medications. They include acute dystonias (involuntary posture or repetitive movement), parkinsonism (muscle rigidity, tremor, bradykinesia, and postural instability as seen in Parkinson’s disease), tardive dyskinesia (involuntary rapid movements), and akathisia (restlessness, constant position shifting)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Complete an assessment of muscle strength and document any impairments
relevant tests and measures.posture: Complete a postural assessment and document any deviations. Dystonias may occur as side effects of medication and may include involuntary postures such as head tilt
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Complete a gross ROM assessment; complete a thorough examination of ROM as indicated by symptoms or reason for referral
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess deep tendon reflexesEvaluate ADLs and document impairments –The Canadian Occupational Performance Measure (COPM) is a tool that has been used with this population(28)
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Patients with schizophrenia will often present with atypical stereognosis and two-point  discrimination
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: The clinician should implement special tests as indicated by reason for referral or patient symptoms –The Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS) is a scale used for measuring symptom severity in patients with schizophrenia(23)
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Arousal, attention, cognition (including memory, problem solving) –Cognitive deficits are common in individuals with schizophrenia and are strongly linked to vocational and functional impairments(5) –Authors of a study designed to identify the cognitive domains most impacted in schizophrenia found that there are sevenspeed of processing, attention/vigilance, working memory, verbal learning, visual learning, reasoning/problem solving, and social cognition(27)

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regards to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls  and educated about fall prevention strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall prevention strategies

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary listed below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Diagnosis/need for treatment Patients with schizophrenia may be referred to physical therapy for the management of other conditions
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Adverse reaction to a prescription medication Use of cocaine or another illicit drug Major organic disorder or increased intracranial pressure Mood disorder with psychotic features, schizoaffective disorder, schizophreniform disorder, delusional disorder, brief reactive psychosis, factitious disorder, malingering, personality disorder (schizotypal, schizoid, borderline, paranoid), and overwhelming anxiety In children, pervasive developmental disorder, thyroid disease, Wilson’s disease, homocystinuria, leukodystrophy, and systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
prognosis: There is no cure for schizophrenia(7)
Roughly 5-6%  of individuals with schizophrenia commit suicide(5)

Individuals with schizophrenia have a greater risk for an untimely death compared to the general population. The heightened risk is related to various factors, including but not limited to increased likelihood of being involved in an accident and presence of comorbid conditions (heart disease)(3,7) –Low participation in health maintenance behaviors increases the risk of chronic disorders(5) ›Referral to other disciplines  (as indicated)
other considerations: The evidence available on the efficacy of dance movement therapy as part of the management of schizophrenia is inadequate, preventing any firm conclusions regarding its implementation for this condition(15) –Based on a Cochrane systematic review –Dance movement therapy was defined as “the psychotherapeutic use of movement as a process which furthers the emotional, social, cognitive, and physical integration of the individual”(15) –The review included one study

Yoga as an add-on  treatment for schizophrenia patients on stabilized pharmacological therapy appears to be beneficial for reducing symptoms and improving social functioning(24) –Based on a randomized controlled trial conducted in India –A total of 119 patients with schizophrenia were randomized to 1 of 3 groups: yoga, exercise, and wait list –The yoga regimen consisted of daily 45-minute  sessions of postures and breathing patterns taught by a certified yoga instructor for 1 month. The exercise group performed supervised resistance and aerobic exercise daily for 45 minutes for 1 month. The wait list group received no treatment during the study period but was offered the choice of yoga or exercise at the end of the study period -The study period was 4 months long, but after the first month, 3 months of follow-up  home practice could not be verified –Outcome measures included the PANSS for measurement of symptoms and the Social and Occupational Functioning Scale (SOFS) –The proportion of patients who had improvements in the PANSS and SOFS scores was higher in the yoga group than the exercise or wait listed groups
treatment summary: The results of a systematic review indicate that exercise therapy might improve mental and physical health in patients with schizophrenia(16)

Occupational therapy interventions using a client-centered recovery-oriented  framework may be beneficial for patients in early stages of recovery(28) –Based on the results of a small study (n = 5) in Denmark, occupational therapy is seen as helpful for learning new strategies for engaging in meaningful occupations, as well as coping with failures

Aerobic exercise might lead to improvements in quality of life and mental health status for individuals with schizophrenia; however, further research is recommended(17) –Based on a randomized controlled trial involving 30 participants –Participants all had a diagnosis of schizophrenia –Subjects were randomized to 1 of 2 groups -Treatment group -Aerobic exercise -3 days/week, 40 minutes/day, 10 weeks in duration -Control group –Outcome measures -Brief Symptom Inventory -Scale for the Assessment of Positive Symptoms -Scale for the Assessment of Negative Symptoms -World Health Organization Quality of Life Scale –Turkish  Version –Results (outcomes compared to baseline measurements) -Treatment group demonstrated -A significant decrease in the Scale for the Assessment of Positive Symptoms -A significant decrease in the Scale for the Assessment of Negative Symptoms -A significant decrease in the Brief Symptom Inventory -A significant increase in the World Health Organization Quality of Life Scale – Turkish Version points -No significant changes were detected in the control group

Individuals with schizophrenia who participate in an aerobic and resistance training program might experience an improvement in mental health status as well as acquire gains in strength; however, further research is warranted to support these findings(18) –Based on a small randomized controlled trial (pilot study) involving 13 individuals –Participants all had schizophrenia or a schizoaffective disorder –Subjects were randomized to one of two groups (for 12 weeks) -Treatment group – 2x/week, aerobic and resistance training -Standard care –Outcome measures -6MWT -Muscle strength -Anthropometric measures -Mental Health Inventory (MHI) –Results (outcomes compared to baseline measurements) -The intervention group demonstrated a statistically significant increase in strength -The intervention group demonstrated a statistically significant increase in total MHI score

A regular exercise program was reported to assist in weight management and lead to improvements in general health status in individuals with schizophrenia(19) –Based on a comparative study involving individuals with a diagnosis of schizophrenia, schizoaffective disorder, or bipolar disorder; all subjects were taking antipsychotic medications (which can lead to weight gain) –One hundred thirty individuals participated -Seventy individuals were placed in the exercise group (also included dietary recommendations); exercise program took place over 18 months, 2x/week, for 1 hour each session -Sixty individuals were placed in the control group  –Outcome measures -Anthropometric measurements, plasma lipid-lipoprotein profile, and fasting plasma glucose concentrations -Serum concentrations of prolactin, thyrotropin-stimulating  hormone (TSH), and glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) -The Clinical Global Impression (CGI) scale, the Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS), and the Short Form 36 (SF-36) Health Survey –Results -Twenty participants dropped out (9 in the control group and 11 in the exercise group) -Exercise group -Significant decrease in body weight -Significant increase in high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol -Significant decrease in low-density  lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol -Significant decrease in triglycerides -Significant improvement in the SF-36  (compared to baseline) -Control group -Significant increase in body weight -Significant increase in LDL cholesterol -Significant increase in triglycerides – . desired outcomes: Improved quality of life–Short Form -36 or Short Form -12 (SF 36/SF12)–Heinrich-Carpenter  Quality of Life Scale (QLS)
outcome measures: Implement appropriate outcome measures as indicated by reason for referral

maintenance or prevention: Risk reduction: decrease environmental stressors such as use of street drugs or alcohol and social isolation
Encourage compliance with schizophrenia treatment plan, including prescribed pharmacological agents and psychosocial counseling, medical monitoring, and social support
